The Idaho National Laboratory's groundbreaking work to develop new nuclear power technology was prominently featured in a 9-minute segment on the PBS NewsHour this week. INL Director Mark Peters is a key source, telling PBS, "We’re restarting and testing infrastructure to start to develop the next generation of nuclear power. So I’m just incredibly excited about the fact that we’re finally starting to get a public dialogue going now that it’s important to build the next generation."  The segment begins in Idaho and includes cool archival video from INL, which produced the nation's first nuclear power in 1951 to light the city of Arco. The piece is a coproduction with NOVA l PBS, which will air a full-length documentary, "The Nuclear Option," on Jan. 11. It's great to see Idaho's tech sector get the attention it deserves.

Veterans beware of an effort by a phone line imposter to obtain your credit or debit card information. The attempt mimics the phone number for the Veterans Choice Program (VCP).  The correct toll-free line for VCP is 1-866-606-8198. That line will state you have reached the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs and takes questions about VCP eligibility and other inquiries.  The "mimic" line is 1-800-606-8198. If you dial this number, you will be offered a $100 "retail rebate" for shopping. After getting your name and address, the call center asks for a credit or debit card to cover a $4.95 shipping and activation fee. Do not supply this information.   The Department of Veterans Affairs has issued a warning and reported the matter to the Inspector General for possible civil or criminal investigation. If you know a veteran who might be calling VCP, please inform them of this warning.

Phebe Mack, with her back to the camera, interpreted for me, translating American Sign Language from Anthony Natale, who appears on the screen from California. Natale, a community relations manager, is also an actor and his ASL was so expressive I was able to capture much of his meaning by simply watching.   Salt Lake City-based Sorenson Communications has over 100 centers in North America, employing about 5,000 video relay sign language interpreters, with 40 of  those in Meridian. The company also provides caption calling services and has about 900 employees in Meridian. I met with workers who talked about how they chose their profession. Many have deaf or hard-of-hearing relatives and some simply have an interest in improving communication. The calls range from life-changing moments like announcing the birth of a child to the daily routine of ordering pizza. My thanks to all those who took time to meet me and to Sorenson executives Michael Maddix and Jed Patton for setting up the tour.

A new report from the Idaho Department of Lands - Idaho Land Board provides new evidence that active forest management reduces wildfire risk. The study of fires categorized by land ownership shows fires burned at a considerably higher rate on federal lands, which suffer from inadequate management due to environmental and process restrictions. The report covers the 2007 to 2017 fire seasons.  Federal lands make up 63 percent of the land in Idaho but accounted for 86 percent of the fires in the 11-year period. State ownership makes up 5 percent of the acreage and accounted for 4 percent of acres burned. Thirty percent of the land is in private ownership, where 8 percent of the acres were burned. Tribal ownership equals 2 percent of the land, where 2 percent of the acreage burned.  Put another way, 6.2 million acres of the 33.6 million acres of federal land burned, or 18.5 percent. Fires burned 280,000 acres of the 2.7 million state-owned acreage, or 10.3 percent. Private lands had 603,000 acres burned, of a total of 16 million acres, or 3.8 percent. Finally, 125,000 acres of the 935,000 acres of tribal lands burned, or 13.3 percent.   We can't let this pattern continue. That's why I'm an original cosponsor of the Resilient Federal Forests Act, H.R. 2936. We're fighting for a floor vote in the House, which passed a similar bill in 2015. With all the disastrous wildfires of 2017, my hope is the Senate will take up the bill this year.  It's time to restore multiple-use management of our federal lands and revive our forests and rural communities. Click below to read the Department of Lands report.
